{{Primary sources|date=July 2008}} {{Infobox software | screenshot = [[File:SysLinux.png|250px]] | caption = Screen-shot | developer = [[H. Peter Anvin]] | latest release version = 4.04 | latest release date = {{release date|2011|04|18}} | operating system = [[Linux]] | genre = Boot loader | license = [[GNU General Public License]] version 2 or later | website = http://syslinux.zytor.com }} The '''SYSLINUX Project''' is a suite of lightweight [[IBM PC compatible|IBM PC]] [[Master boot record|MBR]] [[bootloader]]s for starting up [[computer]]s with the [[Linux kernel]]. It is the work of [[H. Peter Anvin]], and consists of several separate systems, the best-known of which is '''ISOLINUX'''.
==List== * The original SYSLINUX, used for booting from [[File Allocation Table|FAT]] filesystems (such as floppy disks and USB drives). * ISOLINUX, used for booting from [[CD-ROM]] [[ISO 9660]] filesystems. * PXELINUX, used for booting from a network server using the [[Preboot Execution Environment]] (PXE) system. * EXTLINUX, used to boot from [[Linux]] [[ext2]]/[[ext3]]/[[ext4]] or [[btrfs]] filesystems. * MEMDISK, used to boot older operating systems like [[MS-DOS]] from these media. * Two separate menu systems. * A development environment for additional modules.
==Use== ===SYSLINUX and ISOLINUX=== SYSLINUX is not normally used for booting full Linux installations since Linux is not normally installed on FAT filesystems. Instead, it is often used for boot or rescue floppy discs, [[Live USB]]s, or other lightweight boot systems. ISOLINUX is generally used by Linux [[Live CD]]s and bootable install CDs.
A minor complication is involved when booting from CD-ROM. The [[El Torito (CD-ROM standard)|El Torito standard]] allows for booting in two different modes: ; Floppy emulation mode: the boot information is stored in an image file of a [[FAT]]-formatted floppy disk, which is loaded from the CD and then behaves as a virtual floppy disk. This mode uses SYSLINUX. ; No emulation mode: the boot information is stored directly on the CD (not in a floppy image). This mode uses ISOLINUX. To have this choice is sometimes useful, since ISOLINUX is vulnerable to [[BIOS]] bugs; for that reason, it's handy to be able to boot using SYSLINUX. This mostly affects computers built before about 1999, and, in fact, for modern computers no emulation mode is generally the more reliable method.
The use of SYSLINUX for the creation of Live USBs is growing, though, and allowing the creation of distributions like [[Slax]] that allow users to try Linux with complete interactivity and persistent changes without needing to install it on their hard disk.
===PXELINUX=== PXELINUX is used in conjunction with a [[Preboot Execution Environment|PXE]] compliant [[Read-only memory|ROM]] on a network card. The PXE environment uses [[Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol|DHCP]] or [[BOOTP]] to enable basic [[TCP/IP]] networking, then downloads a [[booting|bootstrap]] program via [[Trivial File Transfer Protocol|TFTP]]. This bootstrap program loads and configures a [[Kernel (computer science)|kernel]] according to directives that are also downloaded from the TFTP server.
Typically, PXELINUX is used for Linux installations from a central network server or for booting [[Diskless node|diskless workstations]].
===EXTLINUX=== EXTLINUX is typically used as a general-purpose bootloader, similar to [[LILO (boot loader)|LILO]] or [[GNU GRUB|GRUB]]. Since Syslinux 4, EXTLINUX has been merged with SYSLINUX.
== Hardware Detection Tool (HDT) == Since the 3.74 release, the Syslinux project hosts the [http://hdt-project.org Hardware Detection Tool (HDT)] project. This tool is a Syslinux com32 module that displays low-level information for any x86 compatible system. It provides both a command-line interface and a semi-graphical menu mode for browsing. HDT is available as com32 file, a bootable ISO, a 2.88MB floppy disk.
